Steven Howard, member of the
staff of the Levering Y and in
charge of the Room at the Top,
expressed his dissatisfaction with
the lack of cooperation of the
Hopkins administration in the
planned removal of the wall of
the Y's second floor coffee house.
Howard said,"I regret that the
wall hasn't been removed, but
this failure is due to certain administrative difficulties of inertia
beyond my control." He added
that the operation could be accomplished in one day, but that
thus far he has been unable to
have the university send a contractor to provide an estimate
for the job.
The removal of the wall would
connect the Room at the Top
with an adjoining chamber, providing twice as much space as is
presently available. A sliding
glass partition would allow the
two rooms to be used separately
when not functioning as the
Room at the Top.
Tomorrow night, the Room at
the Top will feature accordionist
Mordechai Pinkus and vocalist
Rachel Cohen in a program of
Israeli songs. In addition, a collection of art work featuring
woodcuts, lithographs, and etchings from Beloit College in Wisconsin will be on display, with
individual works for sale at reasonable prices. Another first will
be the presence of waitresses, recruited from local high schools.

To The Editors:
The construction of the new
library on our campus has given
us an important new edifice of
both educational and esthetic
value. Great expense is being
taken to provide us with the
most modern, efficient library
service possible and at the same
time to create pleasant and comfortable surroundings.
It is with some dismay therefore that the Student Council
has received reports from the
University Librarian, Mr. Berthel, that unnecessary and unfortunate acts of vandalism
have occurred. No accusations
have been made, but each of us
who use the library should feel
in part responsible for it. Its
maintenance and services are
dependent upon our treatment.
The Student Council realizes
that it is not its place to try to
police students using the library
facilities, but it is the place for
each student to police himself.
We encourage each member of
the Hopkins community to develop a feeling of pride and responsibility toward the new library. Use the facilities to their
fullest but in so doing, try to
maintain them. Things such as
keeping your shoes off the furniture or not breaking through the
emergency door& will help.

And Chances Are
He'll Turn into a Bear
In some cases an A.B. degree serves as certificate
of admittance to the class of homo superior, if the holder
happens to be a graduate student. Such a certificate
ostensibly entitles bearer to think of undergraduates as
a lower form of life, uneducated and unfit for association. Such graduate students are not usually bears, so
much as they are bees. Having tasted the sweet dew of
some academic success, having received a first degree
though harassed by the bears in the process, these bees
are quick to sting the undergraduates flung into their
path by the system which provides the bears. No one
can be more self-important than a graduate student,
unless one is a faculty member.
A position on the faculty of one of the nation's
most prestigious universities (a graduate school of
great renown, that is) sometimes turns men into bears.
Bears scowl.
Why must a position of certified expertise be construed as entailing the rights of a god, junior grade?
While we might understand arrogance on the part of
an expert while he is dealing with matters in his own
field, we would not then excuse it. It is more perplexing,
however, that one's superiority in amount or integration
of knowledge should result in his being convinced of
some total human superiority. Knowledge seems to
breed contempt for those who know less.
Undergraduates deserve no exoneration in this
kangaroo conviction. Student leaders, nice guys though
most of them are, can he very officious in matters of
state, and somtimes outrage even the Arews-Letter by
their self-importance.
In some of the better undergraduate scholars, one
may observe the attitudes of the noisome bees developing as they grow into graduate students, and even the
most common of the undegraduates can scoff at the
"Metoy-poloi."
Perhaps academic truth sets one free, liberates
one from the chains of common courtesy and respect
due any man who has not proven himself unworthy.
Perhaps an academic license provides such liberty.
We are aware that though we may all be made of
the same clay, a vase is not a jug. It must take some
doing to mold the clay of any man into the fine interior
and exterior of a well-wrought human urn, but consider
the difficulty of getting the same product when you have
to work with bees or bears.

Commencement Day
While seniors are keeping a wary eye on both the
drop date and graduate school application deadlines,
tho6e hard-working souls in the President's office and
in the office of special events are casting about for a
commencement speaker.
"Who," they wonder, "should we invite?" Earl
Warren? Clark Kerr? Andrew W yeth? Dwight MacDonald? Dean Rusk? A Hopkins faculty member? Pinky Lee?
Everyone has his own choice for commencement
speaker, but no one can say just why his man is the
one best suited for the honor. No one, it must be said,
really knows just what a commencement speaker is for.
Should he deliver the final words of wisdom to the
graduates or should he deliver the first cruel words of
the adult (i.e., working) world? Should he be a government official who will explain government policy, or can
we assume that Hopkins students do read newspapers?
Or, as some suspect, should he be a vehicle by which
Hopkins can get national publicity.
We believe that the role of the commencement
speaker is none of these. Commencement day should
include a pause allowing the student to reflect upon his
nature, his achievements, his frustrations, and his
aspirations. A simple, well-chosen poetry reading might
stimulate such reflection far better than soaring rhetoric.
The beauty of Beethoven's Third Symphony or
Tchaikovsky's Sixth as played by a superb orchestra
might stimulate such reflection far better than the cold
logic of a brilliant educator or statesman.
Commencement is perhaps the most significant day
in the life of the University. It is, in fact, significant
enough so that every facet of it should be planned for
a reason.

And Chances Are
He'll Turn into a Bear
In some cases an A.B. degree serves as certificate
of admittance to the class of homo superior, if the holder
happens to be a graduate student. Such a certificate
ostensibly entitles bearer to think of undergraduates as
a lower form of life, uneducated and unfit for association. Such graduate students are not usually bears, so
much as they are bees. Having tasted the sweet dew of
some academic success, having received a first degree
though harassed by the bears in the process, these bees
are quick to sting the undergraduates flung into their
path by the system which provides the bears. No one
can be more self-important than a graduate student,
unless one is a faculty member.
A position on the faculty of one of the nation's
most prestigious universities (a graduate school of
great renown, that is) sometimes turns men into bears.
Bears scowl.
Why must a position of certified expertise be construed as entailing the rights of a god, junior grade?
While we might understand arrogance on the part of
an expert while he is dealing with matters in his own
field, we would not then excuse it. It is more perplexing,
however, that one's superiority in amount or integration
of knowledge should result in his being convinced of
some total human superiority. Knowledge seems to
breed contempt for those who know less.
Undergraduates deserve no exoneration in this
kangaroo conviction. Student leaders, nice guys though
most of them are, can he very officious in matters of
state, and somtimes outrage even the Arews-Letter by
their self-importance.
In some of the better undergraduate scholars, one
may observe the attitudes of the noisome bees developing as they grow into graduate students, and even the
most common of the undegraduates can scoff at the
"Metoy-poloi."
Perhaps academic truth sets one free, liberates
one from the chains of common courtesy and respect
due any man who has not proven himself unworthy.
Perhaps an academic license provides such liberty.
We are aware that though we may all be made of
the same clay, a vase is not a jug. It must take some
doing to mold the clay of any man into the fine interior
and exterior of a well-wrought human urn, but consider
the difficulty of getting the same product when you have
to work with bees or bears.

Commencement Day
While seniors are keeping a wary eye on both the
drop date and graduate school application deadlines,
tho6e hard-working souls in the President's office and
in the office of special events are casting about for a
commencement speaker.
"Who," they wonder, "should we invite?" Earl
Warren? Clark Kerr? Andrew W yeth? Dwight MacDonald? Dean Rusk? A Hopkins faculty member? Pinky Lee?
Everyone has his own choice for commencement
speaker, but no one can say just why his man is the
one best suited for the honor. No one, it must be said,
really knows just what a commencement speaker is for.
Should he deliver the final words of wisdom to the
graduates or should he deliver the first cruel words of
the adult (i.e., working) world? Should he be a government official who will explain government policy, or can
we assume that Hopkins students do read newspapers?
Or, as some suspect, should he be a vehicle by which
Hopkins can get national publicity.
We believe that the role of the commencement
speaker is none of these. Commencement day should
include a pause allowing the student to reflect upon his
nature, his achievements, his frustrations, and his
aspirations. A simple, well-chosen poetry reading might
stimulate such reflection far better than soaring rhetoric.
The beauty of Beethoven's Third Symphony or
Tchaikovsky's Sixth as played by a superb orchestra
might stimulate such reflection far better than the cold
logic of a brilliant educator or statesman.
Commencement is perhaps the most significant day
in the life of the University. It is, in fact, significant
enough so that every facet of it should be planned for
a reason.
